headline.main: Planned Parenthood Ads to Target Romney

docs.abstract: Planned Parenthood is unveiling one of its biggest-ever political advertising campaigns aimed at using Mitt Romney's own words to undermine his support among women.
docs.snippet: Planned Parenthood is unveiling one of its biggest-ever political advertising campaigns aimed at using Mitt Romney's own words to undermine his support among women.

docs.lead_paragraph: A lobbying effort by Endo Pharmaceuticals led to language in a House measure requiring the F.D.A. to develop new ways of measuring the equivalence of “locally acting” generic and brand-name medicines.

headline.seo: Drug Maker Endo Gets Input in House Bill on Generics
headline.main: Drug Maker Seeks Protection Within Bill Favoring Generics
headline.print_headline: Drug Maker Seeks Protection Within Bill Favoring Generics

docs.abstract: Bill with bipartisan support would speed government approval of lower-cost generic copies of brand-name drugs but lobbying effort by Endo Pharmaceuticals, concerned about its most lucrative brand-name product, leads to changes in House version of bill; new provision in measure requires the Food and Drug Administration to develop ways of measuring the equivalence of generic and brand-name medicines.
docs.snippet: A lobbying effort by Endo Pharmaceuticals led to language in a House measure requiring the F.D.A. to develop new ways of measuring the equivalence of “locally acting” generic and brand-name medicines.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the course of the Republican primary campaign, Mitt Romney took pains to convince socially conservative activists that he believes in them, understands their passions and would be an advocate for their causes in the Oval Office. Now, Planned Parenthood is unveiling one of its biggest-ever political advertising campaigns aimed at using Mr. Romney's own words to undermine his support among women - a critical voter group among whom he already trails President Obama.
docs.abstract: Caucus column; Planned Parenthood is unveiling one of its biggest political advertising campaigns ever, aiming to use presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney's own words to undermine his support among women, a critical group of voters among whom polls show he already trails Pres Obama. (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: International PATCHING TROOPS TOGETHER, ONE ACHE AT A TIME
docs.snippet: International     PATCHING TROOPS TOGETHER, ONE ACHE AT A TIME

docs.lead_paragraph: In talks about reducing the nation's exploding health care costs, the ''R'' word - rationing - strikes fear into the hearts of both patients and doctors. Why, many people ask, shouldn't the richest country in the world spend whatever is necessary to protect and preserve its citizens' health? This is the philosophy under which our health care system operates, and it promises to bankrupt us without necessarily improving our health.

headline.main: Personal Health: Trimming a Bloated Health Care System

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column argues that in order to rein in exploding health care costs, expectations will have to change, and incentives for tremendous waste must be reckoned with; argues that without these shifts, a rationing system will eventually become necessary. Drawing (M)

headline.main: POSTINGS | RECENT ENTRIES FROM OUR BLOGS

docs.abstract: Paula Span The New Old Age blog describes study finding that a full 33 percent of the elderly owe more in medical expenses at their time of death than their assets can cover; David J Flaspohler Scientists at Work blog describes his work studying the effects of human activities on birds in Hawaii. (M)/
docs.snippet: The New Old Age     Paula Span posted to nytimes.com/newoldage:

docs.lead_paragraph: Patients who undergo colonoscopy usually receive anesthesia of some sort in order to ''sleep'' through the procedure. But as one Long Island couple discovered recently, it can be a very expensive nap. Both husband and wife selected gastroenterologists who participated in their insurance plan to perform their cancer screenings. But in both cases, the gastroenterologists chose full anesthesia with Propofol, a powerful drug that must be administered by an anesthesiologist, instead of moderate, or ''conscious,'' sedation that often gastroenterologists can administer themselves.

headline.main: The Consumer: Waking Up to Major Colonoscopy Bills

docs.abstract: Many of the 20 million Americans who undergo an outpatient colonoscopy every year are left with inflated bills after their gastroenterologists choose full anesthesia; research has shown that as much as $1.1 billion spent on anesthesia for gastrointestinal procedures each year may not be medically necessary. Photos (M)/
